column2: French: [sɛ̃ lo] (listen)) is a commune in north-western France
column3: the capital of the Manche department in the region of Normandy.

column1: Although it is the second largest city of Manche after Cherbourg
column2: it remains the prefecture of the department. It is also chef-lieu of an arrondissement and two cantons (Saint-Lô-1 and Saint-Lô-2).

column1: Saint-Lô has a mild oceanic climate characterised by mild winters and temperate summers. It has an average annual rainfall of 800 to 900 mm (31 to 35 in) per year. Rainfall is quite frequent throughout the year but most abundant in autumn and winter
column2: in connection with the disturbances coming from the Atlantic Ocean. Rarely intense
column3: they often fall in the form of drizzle. The average temperature is 10 °C (50 °F). In winter
column4: the average temperature ranges between 1 and 7 °C (34 and 45 °F). There are between 30 and 40 days of frost per year. In summer
column5: the average temperature lies around 20 °C (68 °F).

column1: Saint-Lô is located in the centre of the department of Manche and is therefore a node of communication between Nord-Cotentin and southern Manche.
Saint-Lô lies halfway along the Coutances–Bayeux axis (RD 972). A bypass road was commissioned in the 1980s to allow the decongestion of the city from the south. To open up the port of Cherbourg
column2: the region and the department decided the construction of a dual carriageway
column3: RN 174. It is a part of the European route E03 and enables direct connection to Rennes and Europe from the south
column4: through the interchange at Guilberville. The southern section now connects Saint-Lô directly to the A84 autoroute
column5: allowing motorway access to Caen and Rennes. The commissioning of the northern section
column6: which is currently under construction
column7: will meanwhile allow access to Cherbourg and England via the Route nationale 13. The construction of the dual carriageway allowed the extension of the small South ring road heading west and its mutation into genuine urban bypass. It has also enabled the creation and expansion of new business zones which contribute strongly to the current growth of the agglomeration.

The French Revolution of 1789 overthrew the administrative division of the France and the capital of the department was temporarily set at Coutances between 1794 and 1796. Saint-Lô took the Republican name "Rocher de la Liberté" [Rock of Freedom] and a tree was planted on the Champ de Mars. The city was relatively untouched during the Reign of Terror although there were some clashes with the Chouans.

The Church of Notre-Dame de Saint-Lô is a monument of Flamboyant Gothic style erected on four centuries from the end of the 13th century to replace the former castle's chapel. It is located in the Enclos surrounded by ramparts and was listed on the register of historic monuments in 1840. The outdoor pulpit was noted and drawn by Victor Hugo
column2: which he called 'unique' in a letter to Adèle Foucher. He protected it from demolition
column3: which was planned prior to town renovation in 1863.

column1: The building suffered heavy destruction during World War II
column2: although it was among the only standing buildings after the 1944 bombings. If the stained-glass windows were saved
column3: after being always present since temporary removal during the war
column4: the nave was gutted following the collapse of the North Tower which was shelled by German artillery. Its roof and façade were destroyed
column5: as well as the top of the other tower. Instead of rebuilding the church identically
column6: the architect of Historic Monuments decided to build a greenschist frontage to highlight the scar left by the war. The statue of Notre-Dame du Pilier is from 1467; having been destroyed and remade several times
column7: it is now housed on a column in the apse chapel.

column1: The abbey church of Sainte-Croix is
column2: according to the tradition
column3: the heir of a chapel built here by St. Helena in the 4th century and of an abbey founded by Charlemagne. More documented is the creation of an Augustinian abbey by the bishop of Coutances in 1132. The Romanesque church was consecrated in 1202
column4: being largely remade in the following centuries with successive renovations. The choir was remade in the 16th century while the bell tower is from 1860 to 1863. During World War II
column5: the bell tower (located laterally) collapsed and it was on its ruins where the body of Major Howie was placed; a new bell tower was rebuilt in 1957 on the forecourt in a modern style. On the church square stands the departmental monument in memory of the victims of the wars of Algeria and Indochina
column6: opened in 2005.

column1: The cemetery of Saint-Lô is located between the Saint-Croix Church and the national stud

column3: also the mausoleum of the Blanchet family
column4: and Major Glover S. Johns Junior who installed the first command post before releasing the city. One can still find the tomb of the French revolutionary general Dagobert. Also note the weeping statue which has traces of shrapnel
column5: a bronze sculpture of Cabet
column6: who was a student of F. Rude.

column1: Saint-Lô is home to the largest of the 23 national stud farms in France. In 1806
column2: Napoleon provided Saint-Lô with a deposit of stallions by the Imperial Decree of 4 July 1806. From its origin
column3: the deposit was installed on buildings and abandoned land of the old Abbey of Sainte-Croix (3 ha (7.4 acres) first leased and then owned from 22 September 1807). The stud then recruited from the breeding of the Haras du Pin.In 1826
column4: the military remount depot moved premises which the stud had given to it; most stallions were taken from the stud to provide cavalry. On 28 May 1874
column5: the Boscher Law enabled supervision of the allocations of the regiments and allowed to provide the stud with over 230 horses. On 28 June 1881
column6: the municipal council decided to transfer the stud to adjoin the Route de Bayeux. Thus
column7: the current stud farm buildings date from 1884 (the first stone was laid on 11 June 1884)
column8: and the transfer was finished three years later. During World War I
column9: five mares out of six were requisitioned
column10: but no stallions. Grooms fought at the front
column11: and German prisoners dug a pond. In 1939
column12: the old stable housed the staff of the Haras de Strasbourg (40 stallions and staff) at the time of the German breakthrough. Then
column14: fifty horses were killed by the bombing and other stallions were stolen by German soldiers in flight. The old stud was destroyed and claimed by the city. Thus
column15: there only remains the street of the same name and the Normandy building which was previously the former riding school. The new stud was then built. General de Gaulle offered to the Sultan of Morocco Bois de Rose
column16: a thoroughbred which had been stationed at the stud for two years. The stud then grew gradually in the field of reproduction
column17: by investing in an artificial insemination centre
column18: a centre for the freezing of semen and an embryo transfer unit. Thus
column19: the electoral district of Saint-Lô has the highest density of breeding deposits of France.

column1: Located on the bank of the Vire
column2: the Château de la Vaucelle belongs to the Saint-Lois descendants of the 17th century diarist Luc Duchemin. The Sainte-Pernelle Chapel is the work of a Lord of the Vaucelle Jean Boucart
column3: confessor of Louis XI and founder of the parish library of Saint-Lô
column4: which was at the time the second library of Normandy by importance. Three kings resided at the Vaucelle: Edward III in 1346
column5: at the beginning of the Hundred Years' War the king found that it was not a safe city
column6: Francis I during his visit in 1532 and Charles IX. The dovecote and the northern wall niche are listed as protected elements.

column1: The Chapelle de la Madeleine is located right next to the national stud

A memorial was inaugurated in May 1995 in honour of the soldiers of the 29th and 35th divisions who liberated Saint-Lô in 1944. Photos

column1: A memorial in the city honours Major Thomas Howie
column2: Commander of the 3d Battalion
column3: 116th Infantry Regiment of the U.S. Army's 29th Division; the unit that liberated the city on 18 July 1944. Howie was killed just before his unit entered the city and was so highly respected that his men placed his flag-draped body on the hood of a jeep at the front of the column so he could be the first American to enter the city. He became famous as the "Major of Saint-Lô".

column2: the city square is all black asphalt lit by spotlights on the ground. At night it has a resemblance to an airport runway. The statue of the dairywoman or Femme d'Isigny [Woman of Isigny] can be seen at the top of the square. Arthur Le Duc (1848–1918) introduced a plaster statue in 1887
column3: a Norman woman marked by the hard work of the Earth
column4: a milk rod (a typical Normandy container) on her shoulder. A few years later
column5: the bronze arrived in Saint-Lô. It is set on a round plinth
column6: surrounded by a basin
column7: on the Place des Beaux-Regards in front of the Notre-Dame church. She moved a little further when the Poilu of the Great War was installed. It was then unbolted and melted on 8 February 1942
column8: by the Germans
column9: to recover the bronze for the arms industry. In January 1984
column12: wanted to create a replica of this statue. A fundraiser gained significant donations from residents. Once the money was together

It is also the setting of the festival of the Vire which is held annually during the last weekend of June. It also allows access to the piers for boat tours.
